So, weird question - experiments like this are probably all over the internet, so the information is widely available, but if someone like me with a chemistry minor wanted to make an experiment, how would I know a lot of the toxicity information, as well as the reactions that would occur under various circumstances, plus what form the products would take? Like you said, "once it's dried, the products will become a paste". How does someone know that?

To be more specific, I wanted to do an experiment for "how much Citric acid is in 2L Sierra Mist compared to other soft drinks". With citric acid being an acid, I thought I could figure this out with excess baking soda. I tried that, knowing the reaction would lead to citrate, water, and CO2, which would escape as bubbles. I also boiled the solution slightly above 100 Celcius and well below the boiling point of citrate, to remove the water. But I had no idea how to separate out the Natural Flavors, Sugar, and other ingredients. Add on top of that, the end result was a black liquid that smelled like molasses. What that told me was that the major ingredient (water) was removed, the CO2 was removed, and the next major ingredient wasn't sugar, but actually high fructose corn syrup. But nothing precipitated out, so I was at a loss on how to finish this, and the internet had no instances of this experiment having ever been done before, at least, outside of the companies that make the drinks...

So I had to change the experiment to "how much water is in 2L Sierra Mist compared to other soft drinks" since the CO2 was just a product of the citric acid, so the major losses in the volume of the original and the volume of the black stuff was that all the water was boiled off. Still, my question stands: how does someone figure out how to isolate a component of a particular mixture if that experiment hasn't ever been done/recorded? Especially when the products are complex or unspecified like "high fructose corn syrup" or "natural flavors".

I've had these fireworks! What are the more modern version "snakes" that have the same, growing effect from a small tablet, (but plain black, and much skinnier/less) - made of? We should really know not to flush fireworks or *anything* including "common" chemicals and medications. *These end up right in your drinking water and freshwater habitats* - and, in coastal cities, the storm drainage, rerouting of rivers and channelization carries it directly into the ocean, polluting the salt-water habitats, as well.

WE should be more careful when disposing of ALL our fireworks - the colorful smokes and explosions are ALL chemical reactions. We see them go up in big displays, and think it's fine, that it mostly burns away and dissipates at a high enough altitude not to affect the life on the ground - (and the birds tend to either be sleeping at night or stay far away, as do bats) - but what happens afterward, or to the remainder? Fireworks cause extensive air pollution in a short amount of time, leaving metal particles, dangerous toxins, harmful chemicals and smoke in the air for hours. Displays are held by companies who are under federal and state regulations on height of display, location, type and disposal of the remains/cleanup. When you get fireworks from disreputable or unknown sources, from other countries, (maybe even your own) you never know what they may contain, they don't go high enough and the waste always ends up in the air we breathe, the water we drink and the plants we depend on to breathe, eat and harbor life such as birds and bees, which we depend on to survive as a species. Fireworks displays are fleeting, spectacular celebrations of life, but which can kill it. Please be responsible.
